messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 65 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Efficient Pauli channel estimation with logarithmic quantum memory

Paper Abstract: Abstract Here we revisit one of the prototypical tasks for characterizing the structure of noise in quantum devices: estimating every eigenvalue of an nùëõn-qubit Pauli noise channel to error ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon. Prior work [14] proved no-go theorems for this task in the practical regime where one has a limited amount of quantum memory, e.g. any protocol with ‚â§0.99‚Äãnabsent0.99ùëõ\leq 0.99n ancilla qubits of quantum memory must make exponentially many measurements, provided it is non-concatenating. Such protocols can only interact with the channel by repeatedly preparing a state, passing it through the channel, and measuring immediately afterward. This left open a natural question: does the lower bound hold even for general protocols, i.e. ones which chain together many queries to the channel, interleaved with arbitrary data-processing channels, before measuring? Surprisingly, in this work we show the opposite: there is a protocol that can estimate the eigenvalues of a Pauli channel to error ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon using only O‚Äã(log‚Å°n/Œµ2)ùëÇùëõsuperscriptùúÄ2O(\log n/\varepsilon^{2}) ancilla qubits and O~‚Äã(n2/Œµ2)~ùëÇsuperscriptùëõ2superscriptùúÄ2\tilde{O}(n^{2}/\varepsilon^{2}) measurements. In contrast, we show that any protocol with zero ancilla ‚Äì even a concatenating one‚Äì must make Œ©‚Äã(2n/Œµ2)Œ©superscript2ùëõsuperscriptùúÄ2\Omega(2^{n}/\varepsilon^{2}) measurements, which is tight. Our results imply, to our knowledge, the first quantum learning task where logarithmically many qubits of quantum memory suffice for an exponential statistical advantage.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 65 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 65"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The learnability of quantum states",
        "Shadow tomography of quantum states",
        "Online learning of quantum states",
        "Gentle measurement of quantum states and differential privacy",
        "Fault-tolerant quantum computation with constant error",
        "Quantum algorithmic measurement",
        "A survey on the complexity of learning quantum states",
        "The multiplicative weights update method: a meta-algorithm and applications",
        "Improved quantum data analysis",
        "Entanglement is necessary for optimal quantum property testing",
        "Learning quantum processes and hamiltonians via the pauli transfer matrix",
        "The learnability of pauli noise",
        "Tight bounds on pauli channel learning without entanglement",
        "Quantum advantages for pauli channel estimation",
        "A hierarchy for replica quantum advantage",
        "The complexity of nisq",
        "Exponential separations between learning with and without quantum memory",
        "Futility and utility of a few ancillas for pauli channel learning",
        "When does adaptivity help for quantum state learning?",
        "Tight bounds for quantum state certification with incoherent measurements",
        "Toward instance-optimal state certification with incoherent measurements",
        "Adaptive online learning of quantum states",
        "More practical and adaptive algorithms for online quantum state learning",
        "Streaming quantum state purification",
        "Experimental realization of optimal noise estimation for a general pauli channel",
        "Completely positive linear maps on complex matrices",
        "Optimal purification of single qubits",
        "Mixed-state pauli-channel parameter estimation",
        "Quantum certification and benchmarking",
        "Practical quantum error mitigation for near-future applications",
        "Hybrid quantum-classical algorithms and quantum error mitigation",
        "Characterizing large-scale quantum computers via cycle benchmarking",
        "Quantum channel certification with incoherent strategies",
        "Lower bounds on learning pauli channels",
        "Pauli error estimation via population recovery",
        "Efficient estimation of pauli channels",
        "Quantum parameter estimation of a generalized pauli channel",
        "Learning distributions over quantum measurement outcomes",
        "Efficient learning of quantum noise",
        "Fast estimation of sparse quantum noise",
        "Quantum channel estimation and asymptotic bound",
        "Introduction to online convex optimization",
        "Quantum advantage in learning from experiments",
        "Predicting many properties of a quantum system from very few measurements",
        "Information-theoretic bounds on quantum advantage in machine learning",
        "Linear transformations which preserve trace and positive semidefiniteness of operators",
        "The rate of optimal purification procedures",
        "Memory-sample lower bounds for learning with classical-quantum hybrid memory",
        "Benchmarking near-term quantum computers via random circuit sampling",
        "Multi-armed quantum bandits: Exploration versus exploitation when learning properties of quantum states",
        "Scalable and robust randomized benchmarking of quantum processes",
        "Quantum-process tomography: Resource analysis of different strategies",
        "Quantum Computation and Quantum Information",
        "Online learning via sequential complexities.",
        "Optimal parameter estimation of pauli channels",
        "Fault-tolerant quantum computation",
        "Distribution inequalities for the binomial law",
        "Positive functions on c*-algebras",
        "Matrix exponentiated gradient updates for on-line learning and bregman projection",
        "Quantum tomography using state-preparation unitaries",
        "Noise tailoring for scalable quantum computation via randomized compiling",
        "The theory of quantum information",
        "Revisiting online quantum state learning",
        "Assouad, fano, and le cam",
        "Pushing the efficiency-regret pareto frontier for online learning of portfolios and quantum states"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 65 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Efficient Pauli channel estimation with logarithmic quantum memory, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
